Incident.Summary: Vehicle was stopped for moving violations. Upon contact with the driver, the odor of an alcoholic beverage was detected. SFST's was conducted and the driver was placed under arrest for DUI/DWI.

IncidentSuppNarrative.NarrativeText:
In-Car camera and body worn camera operational H-13.

Defendant: Hubb, Prentiss Frank

Date of Birth: 04/10/1960

Time of arrest: 2223 hours

Location: Northbound Route 5 at Pika Drive, Waldorf, Charles County, Maryland, 20601.

Maryland driver's license: H-100-693-261-280

DUI#: 23-187

2nd DUI

CERTIFICATES AND TRAINING

*Trained in administering Standardized Field Sobriety Tests through the Maryland State Police.

*Trained in Advanced Roadside Impaired Driving Enforcement through Charles County Sheriff's Office.

*Trained in Crisis Intervention Team through Calvert County Sheriff’s Office.

NARRATIVE/ VEHICLE IN MOTION (PHASE 1):

On 11/02/2023 at approximately 2200 hours, I, Tpr. Tripp #7333 with the Maryland State Police La Plata Barrack “H” was traveling in lane two on northbound Mattawoman Beantown Road in the area of Poplar Hill Road, Waldorf, Charles County, Maryland 20601. I observed a blue Ford F-150 traveling in lane one on northbound Mattawoman Beantown Road in the area of Poplar Hill Road, changing lanes unsafely. The blue Ford crossed over into lane two approximately one tires length for four seconds before merging back into lane one. The vehicle then comes to a complete stop in lane one and makes a U-turn going to towards Route 5 (Leonardtown Road). I then make a U-turn to follow the vehicle, following the blue Ford onto northbound Route 5 in the area of Mattawoman Beantown Road. I observed the vehicle travel in lane two, cross over into lane one approximately two tires length for two seconds. I observed the vehicle cross into the right turn lane approximately one tires length for two seconds before merging back into lane two. I observed the vehicle merge onto lane one and cross into lane two approximately one tires length for two seconds before merging back into lane one. I then observed the vehicle cross over into the left turn approximately two tires length for three seconds before merging back into lane one. I then activate my emergency equipment and stopped the vehicle in lane two at Northbound Route 5 in the area of Pika Drive, Waldorf, Charles County Maryland.

PERSONAL CONTACT (PHASE 2):

Once I approached the vehicle, I immediately detected the strong odor of an alcoholic beverage emitting from the vehicle. The driver stated “How are you doing sir?”, I then stated “I’m doing good.” The driver repeated the question two more times. The driver then states “my neighbor is a sheriff officer.” The driver then hands me temporary registration card. I advised the driver I need his license and registration, which he displayed. I was able to identify the driver through his Maryland driver’s license as, Hubb, Prentiss Frank (1/M, DOB:04/10/1960). While speaking with Hubb, I observed his eyes to be bloodshot and glassy. While speaking with Hubb, I observed his speech to be slow and slurred. I asked Hubb if he had consumed any alcoholic beverages, he advised “Yes.” I then asked what kind of alcoholic beverages did he consume, he advised “A beer.” Hubb also stated “My son had one hell of a game, so I celebrated.” Once I approached the vehicle again I then noticed Hubb was chewing on mint. I requested Hubb to perform Standardized Field Sobriety Test’s (SFST’s), which he agreed to take only the first test (Horizontal Gaze Nystagmus test). Before Hubb approached to the front of the vehicle he stated “If you suspect me of being drunk, let’s just go through the process.” Hubb also stated “If you’re going to lock me up then lock me the fuck up and let me move on.” As Hubb approached the front of his vehicle, I continued to detect the strong odor of an alcoholic beverage emitting from his breath and person.

PRE-ARREST SCREENING (PHASE 3):

TFC Leone #6678 assisted with the traffic stop. I asked Hubb if he had any medical conditions, I should be aware of, he advised “No.” I asked Hubb if he had any head injuries or concussions, he advised, “Maybe, I’ve been hit in the head.” I then asked Hubb was it within the past week, he advised, “Yes.” Hubb then stated “I didn’t go to the doctor, if that’s what you’re asking me, no.” I then asked Hubb does he wears glasses or contacts, he advised he wears reading glasses. I asked Hubb if he is a diabetic or have high blood pressure, he advised, “No.” I asked Hubb if there is anything I should be aware of before conducting the test, he advised "No." I then asked Hubb if he could see the pen displayed approximately 12 inches away from his eyes, he advised, “Yes.”

HORIZONTAL GAZE NYSTAGMUS TEST: (6/6 clues observed).

The first test given was the Horizontal Gaze Nystagmus (HGN) test. The tip of my pen was used as the test's stimulus and held approximately 12 inches from Hubb's eyes. He was instructed to look straight ahead, keeping his head still while following and focusing on the tip of the stimulus with his eyes until told to stop. His pupils were equal in size and showed equal tracking with no resting nystagmus. He was positioned in a manner to ensure the headlights of passing traffic would not interfere with the test results. 

Hubb displayed equal pupil size, equal tracking and no resting nystagmus in both eyes.

Hubb displayed lack of smooth pursuit in both eyes.

Hubb displayed nystagmus at maximum deviation in both eyes.

Hubb displayed nystagmus prior to 45 degrees in both eyes.

VERTICAL GAZE NYSTAGMUS:

Hubb displayed vertical gaze nystagmus in both eyes.

WALK AND TURN: Refusal.

ONE LEG STAND: Refusal.

Hubb was offered the Preliminary Breath Test (PBT) and he refused to take it.

Arrest:

-Strong odor of an alcoholic beverage emitting from his breath and person.

-Bloodshot and glassy eyes.

-Slurred and slow speech

-Admission to drinking alcoholic beverage.

-Clues displayed from the Standardized Field Sobriety Test.

Hubb was placed under arrest for driving under the influence of alcohol at 2223 hours. While arrested Hubb used derogatory terms towards me. Once Hubb was placed into my vehicle, he stated to me multiple times, “I know I messed up.” The DR-15 Advise of Rights was read to Hubb and he agreed to take the Intoximeter Test at 2241 hours. While conducting a search incident to arrest, I located five (5) silver Coors Light mini cans. One can located on the rear passenger side floorboard and the other four cans located on the front passenger side floorboard. I observed two Coors Light cans were empty. One (1) partially empty Salignac Cognac (40% alcohol) was located in the center console of the vehicle. Hubb was then transported to the Maryland State Police La Plata Barrack for further processing. Once Hubb arrived at the La Plata Barrack, I explained to him the DR-15 Advise of Rights again, which he then refused to take to the test at 2306 hours. While at the La Plata Barrack Hubb continued to state to me, “I know I messed up.”

Hubbs received the following citations:

TA-21-902(a1i) Driving under the influence of alcohol.

TA-21-902(b1i) Driving while impaired by alcohol.

TA-21-901.1(a) Reckless Driving.

TA-21-901.1(b) Negligent Driving.

TA-21-201(a1) Driver failure to obey traffic control device instructions.

TA-21-309(b) Unsafe Lane changing.

TA-21-1407 Stopping on authority highway when prohibited.

Hubb was transported to Charles County Detention for further processing.

Hubb was rude the entire process.

All events occurred in Charles County, Maryland.

Case closed.
